09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788 (20:34): hey, why instead of use ie conditional comments, to remove extra require, use only style.css then ie css hacks?

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:35): 09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788, can you rephrase that? =/
09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788 (20:35): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: srry, for my english, let's try again
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (20:35): somewhere. see paul hayes blog on media query transition something
09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788 (20:36): Why instead use IE conditional comments, we don't use only one stylesheet then use css hacks for ie?
09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788 (20:36): Doing that we remove extra request
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:36): because it's much cleaner.
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:36): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: and will it work for complex cases like -webkit-transform: rotate() scale() translate(); ?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (20:37): 09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788: the vogue thing to do is conditional classnames on the <html>
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:37): the extra requests only occur for browsers that understand and match the conditional CSS
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:37): 09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788 http://paulirish.com/2008/conditional-stylesheets-vs-css-hacks-answer-neither/
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:37): so if Firefox loads the page, it sees the conditional CSS, and ignores it because it's not IE6, for instance.
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (20:37): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: you want to hit-test? you can. you'll have to write it though.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:37): that saves bandwidth, and keeps your "this is really bad styling" css well away from your "this is proper css"
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:39): allows for proper css without hacks and all in 1 stylesheet
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:39): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: I don't want to do intersection, no
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:39): stylesheets are semantic in and of themselves. Any stylesheet you include represents a something.
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (20:39): i don't know what you're asking for
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:39): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: I just want to see if el.style.WebkitTransform = 'blah'; will actually fire a el.addEventListener('webkitTransitionEnd')
09c963b1a743114a322c5e9823ad5788 (20:40): srry for my english
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:40): wont you 'see' only if it fires?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (20:40): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: there is a list of transitionable style properties
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:40): how can you 'see' otherwise.
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:40): 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: if it's not going to transition, I need to call a callback right then
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:40): yeah or you need to watch properties changing
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:40): o yeah you cant
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:40): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: -webkit-transform is transitionable
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:41): write a zero second transition?>
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:41): i dont think thats specced yet.
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:41): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: if it's to the same value it doesn't fire a transition
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:41): no, but as test it'll work.
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:41): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: no the idea of triggering a call back when a transition is NOT fired
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:41): on page launch do a 0s transition, then if the property is set to the transition value but the event didn't fire, problem.
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:42): basically a transition is cancelled but there is no event associated with it.
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:42): ok, tiny bit more context
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:42): to move between apps / most visited on Chrome's NTP we use -webkit-transform: translate3d(-1579px, 0, 0);
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:42): and to do it animatedly, we add -webkit-transition: -webkit-transform 200ms;
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:43): if we have a no-op movement (which we can have)
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:43): I'd like to know if there will actually be a transitionEnd
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:43): as the method I'm creating has a callback that needs to be fired when you're on the correct page
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:43): so doing a 0s transition doesn't help
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:44): and when you set the .WebkitTransform it modifies the style
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:44): so I don't really want to trust that
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:44): i.e. .WebkitTransform = 'translate3d(-157px, 0, 0)' -> 'translate3d(-157px, 0px, 0px)'
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:44): just a question, because I don't know the setup, why would the noop be implemented as a transition?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (20:45): would detecting the noop and acting on that instead not make more sense?
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:45): well, I might have to not do this
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:45): but it brought up a bigger question
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:45): of telling if this was possible for any property, not just this case
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:45): I'm really looking for a generic way to tell if a webkitTransitionEnd will fire
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:46): you cant tell IF it would fire, only when it does. i wish there was a case where you can know when it is cancelled.
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:47): 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: can you even cancel?
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:47): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: yes if another transition occurs that causes said cancellation.
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:47): lol, that's not a cancel, though, right?
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:47): it's just another interpolation on top, ya?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (20:47): .bind('webkitTransitionError', ..
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:48): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: no if you have multiple transitions that trigger on various events. one of them cancels the other
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:48): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: does that actually exist?
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (20:48): not that that exists...

2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:50): 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: the closest we've come to programmatically cancelling / affecting transitions is to manually set -webkit-transition-duration: 0; to fast forward to the end (s/-webkit/-o|-moz|-ie?/)
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:50): 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: but I guess you can do it the way you mention, as well, didn't know that, cool!
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (20:51): you could look at some of these transition tests that webkit/ff team wrote to look at some usecases.

2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:54): it's probably better for my use case - has start/iteration/end
